msItem.title: Sayings
msItem.incipit: b recto Natura nil agit frustra
msItem.explicit: b verso Bos loquitur arranti. In breui deficient homines quam iumenta vel vt quidam libri habent ffrumenta
msItem.note: The sayings are mostly anonymous but one is attributed to Augustinus and another to Ptholomeus philosophus.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for whitening teeth
msItem.rubric: c recto ffor to scowre a mans teth and make thame whyte
msItem.incipit: c recto Take salt and barly mele or flowre and wessh þe teth þerwith
msItem.note: Full transcription; not recorded in Angela M. Lucas, Manuscripts in Christ's, Emmanuel, Jesus, Selwyn and Sidney Sussex Colleges, Peterhouse and Trinity Hall, Cambridge, The Index of Middle English Prose, Handlist XXII (Cambridge: Brewer, 2016).

msItem.title: Advice for judges
msItem.rubric: c verso In ffesto omnium sanctorum
msItem.incipit: c verso Iudices iuste iudicent et debent a mente sua omne / cupiditatem excludere . et paupertatem diligere

msItem.title: Saying from the vita of St Lupus of Troyes
msItem.incipit: c verso Nichil nocere boni . verba aliena . quem propria non maculat consciencia.

msItem.title: Extract from Augustine, Enarrationes in Psalmos, Psalm 92
msItem.author: Augustine
msItem.incipit: c verso De malicia mali flagellatur bonus et de seruo emendatur ffilius
msItem.note: A marginal annotation has been partially cropped off but probably read: Augustinus - xciij.

msItem.title: Advice for judges
msItem.incipit: c verso Judices iuste iudicent . a mente sua omnem cupiditatem excludere. et paupertatem diligere . h. in ffestum omnium sanctorum

msItem.title: Mnemonic poem on the Circumcision, excerpt from the Legenda Aurea
msItem.author: Jacobus de Voragine
msItem.rubric: c verso Causeant quare circumcisio data ffuit sunt sex que in hijs versibus continentur
msItem.incipit: c verso versus - Cauterium . signum. meritum . medicina. ffigura / Exemplum ffuit olim . circumcisio dura.

msItem.title: On seven ways of praising God
msItem.incipit: c verso Septem verbis vsitatoribus saecula vtitur ad laudem dei quasi septem iubileorum tubis misticis scilicet 1. laudare. 2. benedicere. 3. magnificare. 4. confiteri. 5. honorificare. 6. glorificare et 7. super exaltare.

msItem.title: Excerpt from De miseria condicionis humanae [De Contemptu Mundi]
msItem.author: Lotario dei Conti di Segni [Pope Innocent III]
msItem.incipit: c verso Caro dum viuit dolebit et aniam super semetipsam lugebit

msItem.title: Tract on access to God, attributed to St Bernard of Clairvaux
msItem.incipit: c verso Securum accessum habes ad deum o homo . vbi mater est ante ffilium et filius ante patrem . mater oscendit filio pectus et vbera filius ostendit patri latus et vulnera nulla ergo poterit esse repulsa vbi tot concurrunt charitatis et insignia

msItem.title: Four punishments for adultery
msItem.incipit: c verso Quatuor hijs casibus sine dubio cadit adulter / Aut hic pauper erit . aut subito morietur. / Aut cadet in causam . qua debet iudie vinci / Aut aliquod membrum casa . vel crimine perdet

msItem.title: Necessary things for a horse rider, courtier or trader
msItem.incipit: d recto wete botys in pluuia . dry buskyns in aurora serena. ynke. paper. pen. parchment. sele. redwax. luke thow shal lake none . thymbyll. cum nedyll. bodkyn. poynte. leste þat þi garth \breke/. cloke. budget. tayke wyth the. þi comme. nyght cappe. leve not be hynde. then rydys thow surely. yff thy spere be not lefte in þe hostry [added in lighter ink: e over the space between the 'r' and 'y', suggesting the spelling hostrey; and, at the end of the line, in the same light brown ink, the word: hostre].
msItem.note: Full transcription; not recorded in Angela M. Lucas, Manuscripts in Christ's, Emmanuel, Jesus, Selwyn and Sidney Sussex Colleges, Peterhouse and Trinity Hall, Cambridge, The Index of Middle English Prose, Handlist XXII (Cambridge: Brewer, 2016).

msItem.title: Unidentified sayings
msItem.incipit: >d recto Quare ad nostram discrecionem pro remedio operis non duxi recurrendum precibus humilibus supplicando quatinus

msItem.title: Tract on the names of the Seven Archangels (Michael, Gabriel, Raphael, Uriel, Raguel, Barachael et Pantasaron)
msItem.incipit: d recto Cum de mane surrexeris . Michaelem in mento habeto et letum diem obtinebit. Cum tonat Gabrielem et non nocebit tibi tonitruum. Cum commederis Raphaelem et omnia habundabunt tibi. Cum veneris contra aduersarium tuum Hurielem et ab eo victoriam accipies. Cum itinere perrexeris Raguelem et omnia prospera euenient tibi. Cum in iudicium ueneris ad aliquem potentem adire uolueris Barachielem et graciam consequeris. Cum ad conuiuium ffueris Pantassaron et omnis congaudebunt tibi
msItem.note: Full transcription; according to James (1895), a copy of a comparable text survives in a 9th- or 10th-century manuscript, now Cologne, Domstiftbibliothek, MS 174, f. 45v (recorded in Philipp Jaffé and Wihelm Wattenbach, Ecclesiae metropolitanae Coloniensis codices manuscripti (Berlin: Weidmannsche Buchhandlung, 1876), p. 73).

msItem.title: Enarrationes in Psalmos, Psalm 93:23
msItem.author: Augustine
msItem.incipit: d recto Neque enim est perfecta dilectio christiani nisi cum implet quod
msItem.explicit: d recto Hinc victorie corona percipitur . hec augustinus super deus vlcionum

msItem.title: 1 Peter 1:25
msItem.incipit: d verso verbum domini manet in eternum

msItem.title: Dietary advice
msItem.incipit: d verso Qui moderatis vescuntur cibariijs ad extremam et nudam perueniunt senectutem

msItem.title: Dietary advice
msItem.incipit: d verso Si sero commederas parum comede et mane te inuenies levem

msItem.title: Sic vos non vobis
msItem.author: Pseudo-Virgil
msItem.incipit: d verso Sic vos non vobis . nidifficatis aues
msItem.explicit: d verso Sic vos non vobis ffertis aratra boves

msItem.title: Excerpt from "Ypocras", De vita et moribus philosophorum
msItem.author: Pseudo-Walter Burley
msItem.incipit: d verso Securitas cum pauperitate eligibilior est quam cum diuicijs timor
msItem.explicit: d verso qui de omni apposito graces [sic: gracias] agit et de defectu rerum non murmurat

msItem.title: Excerpt from the life of St Augustine in the Legenda Aurea
msItem.author: Jacobus de Voragine
msItem.rubric: d verso Augustinus in mensa . Contra detraccionis scriptum ibi in pariete
msItem.incipit: d verso Quisquis amat dictis absentum rodere vitam / hanc mensam indignam nouerit esse sibi

msItem.title: Barlaam and Josaphat
msItem.author: Pseudo-John of Damascus
msItem.rubric: 1r Incipit liber gestorum Barlaam et Josaphat seruorum dei editus greco sermone a Johanne Damasceno viro Sancto et erudito
msItem.incipit: 1r Cum igitur cepissent monasteria construi ac monachorum congregari multitudines
msItem.explicit: 79v Tu autem homo dei vigilanti studio accende que dico et mihi adhuc magis stupenda narranti fidem prebeto
msItem.finalRubric: 79v Explicit Liber Beati Augustini doctoris eximii de conflictu viciorum et virtutum.

msItem.title: Added note on Barlaam and Josaphat
msItem.incipit: 79v In libro qui intitulatur omelie Cesarij Episcopi in paruo armariolo apud Wardon continetur Johannes Cassianus de Institutis Cenobiorum et de octo principalium uitiorum remediis in . xij . libellis
msItem.note: Added in light brown ink in a 14th-century hand. Since the note refers to Wardon in Bedfordshire, James (1895) assumed that it was added by Simon de Gowshill.

Full transcription; also transcribed by James (1895) who transcribes .xij. libellis as .vij. libellis. However, the first Roman numeral does have the ascender that that can be found on versions of the letter x in this script. Moreover, John Cassian wrote De institutis coenobiorum in twelve books.

msItem.title: De veneno
msItem.author: Malachias Hibernicus
msItem.incipit: 80r Racio veneni potissime conuenit peccato
msItem.explicit: 93r In india est quedam gens vbi marito mortuo uxores eius in iudicium veniunt et illa que comprobatur ei magis cara et dilecta defuncto in vita ponitur in sepult[u]ro cum ipso viva et hoc habet viva pro magno aliis derelectis
msItem.finalRubric: 93r Explicit tractactus de veneno et eius remediis

msItem.title: Collection of exempla
msItem.rubric: 93r Exempla super autoritates libri Job. Sub metaphora
msItem.incipit: 93r Multi homines quibus nondum boni mores
msItem.explicit: 96v meliora sunt uulnera diligentis quam fraudulenta oscula odientis.

msItem.title: Comparatio mundi ad ludum schakarum
msItem.author: John of Wales
msItem.incipit: 96v Mundus iste similis est scaccario
msItem.explicit: 97r In isto scacario dicit diabolus Eschek cum aliquid ad infernum per peccatum mortale asportat vel Eschek cum peccat mortaliter cum moritur Mac corporaliter in mortali peccato. dicas ergo Liueret est per confessionem.
msItem.note: A previously unidentified copy of the Comparatio mundi ad ludum schakarum with a hitherto unnoticed passage in Early Middle English on ff. 96v-97r. This passage concerns a verse translation of Baruch 3:16–19, which is quoted (in Latin) immediately before the versified vernacular version, introduced with the word Anglice. The resulting Ubi sunt poem is apparently unique: a more elaborate Middle English Ubi sunt poem of 10 stanzas (beginning: "Uuere beþ they biforen vs weren") survives as part of the poem The blessing of heaven king (see IMEV 3310; NIMEV 3310; DIMEV 5215), but no copies of this direct versification of the Vulgate are recorded in IMEV, NIMEV, or DIMEV.

A full transcription reads:
Were aren alle þis riche men þat haueden stedes in stalle.
hauek and hound was her gle in feld and ek in halle.
gold and siluer he diden in hord he wenden neuer doun falle.
Her soules aren in helle [in] ground her bodies roten alle.
oþer are comen on þeir stede of wam schal als by falle..

msItem.title: Identification of Christ in an account by Valerius Maximus
msItem.author: Valerius Maximus
msItem.incipit: 97r Refert valerius quod quidam civis romanus nobilis genere pro sui delicto coram imperatore iudicandus deducebatur
msItem.explicit: 97r Abisages sunamitis regem prouocabat ad pietatem

msItem.title: Excerpt from the Moralia in Iob, 30, Chapter 25
msItem.author: Pope Gregory I [Gregory the Great]
msItem.incipit: 97r Bellum gedeonis figurat aduentus Saluatoris. Gedeon cum ad bella excercitus produceret diuina admonicione audiuit
msItem.explicit: 97v Quia Christi martires pro magno habebant predicacionis et corporum vtilitatem pro minimo

msItem.title: Sermo de ascensione
msItem.incipit: 98r Relinquo mundum et uado ad patrem
msItem.explicit: 101r Summe trinitatis noticiam quae nobis concedat qui cum patre et spiritu sancte sine fine viuit et regnat Amen

msItem.title: Meditationes 1-9
msItem.author: Pseudo-Augustine
msItem.incipit: 101r Domine deus meus da cordi meus te desiderare desiderando querere querendo invenire inueniendendo amare
msItem.explicit: 104r secundum multitudinem tuarum complaceat miseracionum per ihesum Christum saluatorem meum qui cum patre in tui vnitate viuit et regnat deus per omnia secula seculorum. Amen.

msItem.title: De cognitione verae viteae
msItem.author: Honorius of Autun
msItem.rubric: 104v Augustinus . Incipit prologus de cognicione vere vite
msItem.incipit: 104v Sapiencia dei que os muti aperuit et rudibili animali humana uerba formare tribuit
msItem.explicit: 115r Quia in ea huius glorie consors erit vere vite et omnium beate viuentium faciat te deus participem. Qui nos omnes ad summum bonum perducat. Amen.
msItem.finalRubric: 115r Explicit liber de Cognicione vere veite beti [sic] Augustini

msItem.title: Soliloquium de arra animae
msItem.author: Hugh of Saint-Victor
msItem.rubric: 115v Incipit soliloquium hugonis de arra anime
msItem.incipit: 115v Dilecto fratri G. ceteris seruis Christo hameris leue degentibus .H.
msItem.explicit: 122v Hoc opto. hoc desidero. hoc totis precordiis concupisco

msItem.title: De virtutibus et claustro animae
msItem.author: Johannes de S. Edmundo
msItem.rubric: 122v Incipit summa magistri fratris lohannis de sancto Edmundo de institucione religiosorum seu clericorum secularium circa confessionem. Et diuiditur summa in duas partes. Prima autem pars est de generali confessione in ingressu. Secunda autem pars est de cotidianis confessionibus in progressu quod uidelicet hic euidenter notatur
msItem.incipit: 122v Primo sumitur occasio loquendi ab illo versu prophete In exitu Israel
msItem.explicit: 141r Quem sic uidere est beate vivere et beatum esse uerbi nos ducat ille beatus deus. Cui est honor et gloria in saecula saeculorum. Amen Explicit

msItem.title: Collection of exempla
msItem.rubric: a verso Narraciones perplures ad diuersas materias [title in table of contents]
msItem.incipit: 141r Erat quid miles in anglia qui multum dilexi beatam virginem
msItem.explicit: 144r Cum racionem querentibus respondit. Maluit me in Sepulcro dum viuo includere; quam anime ad ymaginem dei sanctem nocere

msItem.title: Warning not to shed blood, extracted from the Secretum Secretorum
msItem.author: Pseudo-Aristotle
msItem.incipit: 144v Caue ergo in quantum pates ne sanguinem effundere humanam quia doctor egregius hermogines scripsit sic dicens quando creatura interfecit creaturam sibi similem virtutes celorum clamant ad diuinam maiestatem dicentes domine domine seruus tuus vult tibi similis quia sine merito interficit istum. espondit creator excelsus permitte eum quia interfecit et interficietur mihi vindictam et ego retribuam et tociens vel semper virtutes colorum representabunt in suis laudem mortem interfecti donec vindicta sumatur ab interficiente qui erit vnus de persuerantibus in penis eternis

msItem.title: On the distinction between the "holy" and the "blessed"
msItem.incipit: 144v Omnis enim qui confestim vt moritur enolat sanctus esse censetur
msItem.explicit: 144v Beati vero qui post aliquorum purgacionem ad celestia conscendunt

msItem.title: The three most important days of the year to remember
msItem.incipit: 144v Sunt autem tres dies principales quos homo debet habere in memoria continua. scilicet. dies sue natiuitatis. sue mortis. et dies Judicij
msItem.note: Perhaps taken from Raymond of Sabunde's Theologia Naturalis sive Liber naturae creaturarum, written 1434-1436 but published in 1484.

msItem.title: Papal Privilege for the Carthusian Order to retain lay brothers from other monasteries (1187 or 1188)
msItem.author: Clement III
msItem.rubric: [145a] recto Privilegium papale Cartusiensibus de Retinendis fratribus
msItem.incipit: [145a] recto Clemens eipiscopus seruus suorum dei dilectis filijs priori et fratribus Cartusiensis
msItem.explicit: [145a] recto Si vero priuilegiatorum aliquis per annum postquam fratribus domus innotuerit de qua egressus est apud vos non requisitus moram fecerit postea non liceat ei ordinem deserere vel ab ipso per violenciam revocari etcaetera
msItem.note: Written on a smaller parchment leaf that has been sewn to f. 145; copied in the 15th century.

msItem.title: Oculus moralis
msItem.author: Peter of Limoges
msItem.rubric: 146r Hic incipit tractatus moralis de oculo [added title]
msItem.incipit: 146r Si diligenter volumus in lege domini meditari facilime perpendimus ea que pertinent ad visionem
msItem.explicit: 189v Deus enim auferet a iusto oculos suos et reges in so collocat in perpetuum et illuc eriguntur ad illud regnum nos perducat qui sine fine viuit et regnat

msItem.title: Liber Pantheon
msItem.author: Stephanus de Borbone
msItem.rubric: 190r Incipit tractatus de habundancia exemplorum ad omnem materiam
msItem.incipit: 190r Quoniam plus exempla quam verba mouent secundum beatum gregorium et facilius intellectu capiuntur
msItem.explicit: 222r In legenda lohannis Ewangeliste legitur quod quidam iuuenis suscitatus ab eo uiderat demones multum gaudentes de ruina quorundam quos beatus Johannes conuerterat
msItem.finalRubric: 222r Et cetera quere [in] libro qui intitulatur: Bernardus de disciplina monachorum In toto ultimo quaterno in fine libri. Ad tale signum [drawing of a dragon]

msItem.title: Definitions of mental faculties, extract from the Differentiae
msItem.author: Isidore of Seville
msItem.incipit: 222v Dum viuificat anima est. Dum contemplatur spiritus est. Dum sentit sensus est. Dum sapit animus est . Dum intelligit mens est. Dum discernit racio est. Dum sentit voluntas est. Dum recordatur memoria est. et tamen omnia vna anima est.

msItem.title: Distich
msItem.incipit: 222v Cum fueris felix . multos munerabis amicos / Tempora si fuerint . nubilia solus eris
msItem.note: Full transcription; here attributed to Ovid.

msItem.title: Tract on virginity
msItem.incipit: e recto Virginitas est pax carnis . silencium curarum . carcer libidinum . obstruccio sensuum . preco fame . jubilus consciencie . porcio nature angelice . decor membrorum. vite ornamentum . principatus virtitutum . morum fundamentum . Christi cubiculum - virginitas
msItem.note: Full transcription; this excerpt is also found in an anonymous sermon for the feast of Clare of Assisi in Assisi, S. Convento, Fondo Antico Comunale, ms. 565, f. 103v (for an edition, see Aleksander Horowski, 'Chiara D'Assisi in Alcuni Sermoni Mediavali', Collectanea Franciscana, 81 (2011), 645-703 (p. 700)).

msItem.author: Jacobus de Voragine

msItem.title: Description of the four types of wood in the Holy Cross
msItem.incipit: e verso Quatuor ex lignis domini crux dicitur esse. Pes crucis est cedrus corpus tenet ipsa cypressus. palma manus tendit titulo lectura oliua.

msItem.title: A saying
msItem.incipit: e verso fflagellum ergo sibi preparat . qui filios non castigat

extent.seg: iv + 4 + 222 (+ 1 leaf attached to f. 145) + 2 + iv leaves.

foliation.p: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos.

Note that 'f' precedes 'e' in the foliation. It appears that these final two leaves have been swapped around when the manuscript was last rebound. This is suggested by the fact that f verso is blank with remnants of glue, suggesting that this side was once pasted onto the inside of the rear cover, and that the fact that James (1895) describes the contents on these two leaves by referring to them in reversed order, beginning with 'e' which James assigns the number '224', and followed by 'f' (James: '225').

In order to produce a functional electronic catalogue record for this item for the Curious Cures project, the unfoliated modern parchment flyleaves at the beginning and end of this manuscripts were assigned the designations [i]-[iv] and [v]-[viii] and the unfoliated parchment leaf sewn to f. 145r the designation [145a] in September 2023; these designations are enclosed in square brackets in this catalogue record.

foliation.note: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos.

This foliation was added at a later stage but is not followed in this catalogue record since there is no evidence that f. 209 is missing from the manuscript, justifying a jump in the foliation sequence from 208 to 210 as per historical foliation practice.

foliation.p: Numbering in ink in the left-hand margin of the versos. The numbering begins on f. d verso.

collation.p:
This collation deviates from that provided by M.R. James (1895): it includes folios a-d as Quire 1 (omitted by James) and identifies Quire 21 (James: Quire 'v') as originally consisting of 6 leaves and lacking 3 (rather than consisting of 4 leaves).
Quire 16-2 (ff. a-d: 4th and 5th leaves ?missing/excised)
Quire 28 (ff. 1-8)
Quire 314 (ff. 9-22)
Quires 4-612 (ff. 23-58)
Quires 7-88 (ff. 59-74)
Quire 98+8 (ff. 75-90: two quires of eight leaves, one of which (ff. 80-87) is inserted between the 5th and 6th leaves of the other)
Quire 1018 (ff. 91-108)
Quire 1110 (ff. 109-118)
Quire 1212 (ff. 119-130)
Quire 138 (ff. 131-138)
Quire 148-1+1 (ff. 139-145, [145a]: 7th leaf cancelled, and 1 leaf sewn onto the 8th leaf)
Quires 15-1614 (ff. 146-173)
Quires 17-188 (ff. 174-189)
Quire 1914 (ff. 190-203)
Quire 2016 (ff. 204-219)
Quire 216-3 (ff. 220-222: 4th-6th leaves excised, probably blank)

p.formula: 16-2 (4th and 5th missing) 28 314 4-612 7-88 98+8 (8 leaves inserted) 1018 1110 1212 138 148-1+1 (7th cancelled, 1 leaf sewn onto 8th) 15-1614 17-188 1914 2016 216-3 (4th-6th excised)

signatures.p: Usually Arabic or Roman numerals in crayon in the lower right-hand corners of the rectos of the first halves of quires, but, in case of the joint quires 9 and 10 letters of the Roman alphabet in brown ink in the lower right-hand corners of the rectos of all leaves ('a'-'q').

catchwords.seg: Catchwords written in the lower right-hand corners of the last versos of quires, except for Quire 9, where a catchword for Quire 10 was written in the lower margin of the verso of leaf 6.

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame and line ruling. Single columns. 33-45 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Copied by a single early 14th-century hand in Cursiva Anglicana.
The table of contents added by Simon de Gowshill on f. a verso was copied a single early 14th-century hand in a Cursiva Anglicana.
The 15th-century additions on ff. a recto-d verso and ff. 223v-e verso were copied by multiple cursive hands with both Anglicana and Secretary features.

decoNote.p: Drawing of a dragon in red ink, serving a textual symbol, on f. 223r.

One large (8 lines) initial in red with a wavy motif created with blank space and with penwork decoration inside the letter and pen-flourishing extending into the margins in both brown and red ink (f. 1r).
One large (5 lines) initial with penwork inside the letter and pen-flourishing extending into the margins both outlining foliate motifs in red ink (f. 146r).

Large and small (1-5 lines) plain initials in red or brown ink with wavy motifs created by blank areas (e.g. see f. 26v, 52v, 63v, 73v, 74v, 75r [2x], 93r, 123r, 124r, 124v, 128v, 133r, 133v, 190r), sometimes with brown or red penwork decoration inside the letters and brown or red pen-flourishing extending into the margins (ff. 115v, 122v [2x], 128v, 130r, 130v [featuring a human face]).

Large (2-3 lines) plain initials in red ink, some with minor forms of pen-flourishing in red ink extending into the outer margins; once in a framework of blue ink with pen-flourishing in blue ink (f. 146r); and some with brown penwork decoration inside the letters and pen-flourishing extending into the margins (ff. 115v, 130r); from f. 134r, plain initials alternatively in blue or red ink.
Line-fillers consisting of horitontal and diagonal lines, either in brown ink and highlighted with red ink or in brown and red ink.

Ascenders on the first line of f. 1r with human faces drawn in brown ink. Throughout the manuscript, the descenders on last lines extending into lower margins as series of short horizontal and vertical lines either in brown ink with accents in red ink or entirely in red or brown ink.
Rubrics, underlining and marginal notes in red ink.
Small (1 line) initials in brown ink accentuated with red ink.
Paraphs in red ink, but from from f. 134r alternatively in blue or red ink.

Human faces drawn in brown or red ink marking sections of text, including notes in the lower margin of ff. 117r, 211v; and sections on the page in the outer margins of ff. 195v [3x], 196v [1x], and 219v [1x].
Run-over symbols in red (e.g. see f. 12v, 55r) or frames in brown ink (f. 157v).
Catchwords surmounted by red dots and written inside frames of brown or red ink.
Manicules drawn in margins in brown or red ink or in leadpoint; one featuring with a human face (f. 219v).
A tear and sewing thread in f. 28 accentuated with red ink on both sides of the page.

note.p: A table of contents for the manuscript added in a 14th-century hand by Simon de Gowshill to f. a verso

A table of contents for the manuscript added in a (?) 17th-century hand to f. c recto, matching the itemisation of the manuscripts contents in Edward Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (c. 1697).

binding.p: 20th-century red brown leather over wooden boards, 5 raised bands on spine, and blank modern paper leaves pasted on the inside covers.

origin.origDate: First half of the 14th century (probably in the early 14th century).

provenance.p: Owned by Simon de Gowshill (fl. 14th century) Gowshill, Simon de, fl. 14th century, canon and then former prior of the Gilbertine priory of Chicksand, Bedfordshire, founded in 1152 and dissolved in 1538. His ownership inscription in a 14th-century hand on f. a verso: Liber domini Symonis de Gowshille Canonici domus de Chikesond et quondam prioris eiusdem (see Ker (1964), p. 51; and the MLGB3). He may be the same Simon who was prior of Chicksand around and/or between 1310 and 1315 (see 'House of the Gilbertine order: The priory of Chicksand', in A History of the County of Bedford: Volume 1 (London, 1904), pp. 390-393; and British History Online [accessed 27 September 2023]).

Owned by John Stamborn, fl. ? 14th century Stamborn, John, fl. ? 14th century, monk of the Cistercian monastery of Kirkstall Abbey, Leeds, West Yorkshire, founded c. 1152 and dissolved in 1539. His ownership inscription in a ?15th-century hand on f. a verso: Constat Johanni Stamborn monacho de kyrkestall.

Owned by Kirkstall AbbeyKirkstall Abbey, founded c. 1152 and dissolved in 1539. An erased text in a 15th-century hand on f. d verso probably contains its ownership inscription, an ex dono inscription, and the Abbey's book curse: Iste liber [...] de Kyrkestall ex dono [...] [ana]thema sit; most likely followed by an ex dono inscription.

acquisition.p: Acquired by Sidney Sussex College by 1697, when it was recorded as no. 748 in Edward Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (c. 1697). Its old classmark written on f. a verso: Δ.4.23.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on the description provided by M.R. James, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Manuscripts in the Library of Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1895).

availability.p: Visitors to Sidney Sussex College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Archivist in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Sidney Sussex College: Special Collections.
